issue.title: libva error: va_getDriverName() failed with unknown libva error,driver_name=(null)
issue.body:
I'm doing a QT program and I'm getting this error on my Ubuntu (it's a VM):

`libva error: va_getDriverName() failed with unknown libva error,driver_name=(null) `

 I tried all possible solutions on web and they didn't work. 

 I found that `export LIBVA_DRIVER_NAME=i965` could work, but with it, I have the following errors:

```
libva error: /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/dri/i965_drv_video.so init failed
libva error: /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/dri/i965_drv_video.so init failed

```

What can be done?

comment.body:
as I am not sure which of those components is the root cause I also want to point to a current issue with chromium (and chromium based) browsers: 

- https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1491750#c6
- https://github.com/brave/brave-browser/issues/33619#issuecomment-1777571458

issue.title: Segmentation fault with X11 display
issue.body:
Met segmentation fault with MediaSDK(sample_decode h624 -i ~/2.h264 -vaapi -r) or libva samples(libva-utils/putsurface)  whenever X11 is used for display. 

OS: CentOS 7.6 with upgraded kernel version 5.10.14. 
HW: TGL-U i3
libva" 2.9.0

Libva and iHD version:
libva info: VA-API version 1.9.0
libva info: User environment variable requested driver 'iHD'
libva info: Trying to open /usr/lib/dri//iHD_drv_video.so
libva info: Found init function __vaDriverInit_1_9
libva info: va_openDriver() returns 0
vainfo: VA-API version: 1.9 (libva 2.9.0)
vainfo: Driver version: Intel iHD driver for Intel(R) Gen Graphics - 20.3.0 (86ec0b6)
vainfo: Supported profile and entrypoints
      VAProfileNone                   : VAEntrypointVideoProc
      VAProfileNone                   : VAEntrypointStats
      VAProfileMPEG2Simple            : VAEntrypointVLD
      VAProfileMPEG2Simple            : VAEntrypointEncSlice

Software stack by gdb ./putsurface/putsurface : 

Create window0 for thread0
libva info: VA-API version 1.9.0
libva info: User environment variable requested driver 'iHD'
libva info: Trying to open /usr/lib/dri//iHD_drv_video.so
libva info: Found init function __vaDriverInit_1_9
libva info: va_openDriver() returns 0
Loading data into surface 15.....
Enter into thread0


Program received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
0x0000000000000000 in ?? ()
Missing separate debuginfos, use: debuginfo-install glibc-2.17-323.el7_9.x86_64 libX11-1.6.7-3.el7_9.x86_64 libXau-1.0.8-2.1.el7.x86_64 libXext-1.3.3-3.el7.x86_64 libXfixes-5.0.3-1.el7.x86_64 libffi-3.0.13-19.el7.x86_64 libgcc-4.8.5-44.el7.x86_64 libstdc++-4.8.5-44.el7.x86_64 libwayland-client-1.15.0-1.el7.x86_64 libxcb-1.13-1.el7.x86_64
(gdb) bt ful
#0  0x0000000000000000 in ?? ()
No symbol table info available.
#1  0x00007ffff7bd7a9c in do_drawable_hash (drawable=46137345, ctx=0x686410) at va_dricommon.c:74
        dri_state = <optimized out>
        index = 1
        dri_drawable = <optimized out>
#2  va_dri_get_drawable (ctx=0x686410, drawable=46137345) at va_dricommon.c:122
No locals.
#3  0x00007ffff369eff2 in DdiCodec_PutSurfaceLinuxHW (ctx=ctx@entry=0x686410, surface=surface@entry=1, draw=draw@entry=0x2c00001,
    srcx=srcx@entry=0, srcy=srcy@entry=0, srcw=srcw@entry=352, srch=288, destx=0, desty=0, destw=352, desth=288, cliprects=0x0,
number_cliprects=0, flags=0)

comment.body: Was there any other information discovered on this? I know it's been a hot minute but I'm having a very similar issue

pull_request.title: refine encode segment id map buffer
pull_request.body:
attention: these change will break backward compatibility, the pre-assumption is no one is using them besides intel media driver and intel oneVPL runtime, if there are other customer,  it should be risky 
so, please help to check whether there are somebody are using segment id map buffer for avc or vp9 encoding.

issue.title: unable to update latest version
issue.body:
Ubuntu 22.04 8700k 1080Ti

Vainfo was working fine untile I decided to update using autogen and there are duplicate files of libva in /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/. Files are linked and I have no idea how to overwrite or use LD_LIBRARY_PATH. Currently running vainfo looks like this:
`vainfo: symbol lookup error: /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libva-x11.so.2: undefined symbol: va_fool_postp
`

issue.title: jumps in either the video or the audio when using hardware accelleration for video playback
issue.body:
Hey. Shamelessly copying my own bug report at https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/drm/intel/-/issues/9065 from where I was redirected to `libva`.
Not sure whether this is actually an issue in ~i915~ `libva`, since there are probably quite a few other libs/etc. that may be involved.
If you have a better clue, please redirect me accordingly. Let me first describe the issue. Since quite a while now (> 1 year) the following happens when playing back a video with `mpv` (which I've configured to use hw decoding (`hwdec=auto` in `.config/mpv/mpv.conf`):
When I pause the video an wait a while, e.g. leave fullscreen, go do another workspace, do some work, etc. ... after coming back and resuming playback of the video, either right at the beginning of that (or shortly afterwards, like 10s), there are a series of "jumps" in the video. That is I see that the motion is not fluent anymore and the video resumes at a later point.
The audio is **not** affected but play just smoothly.
The jumps are first longer (may 1 second or perhaps 2 at most... maybe also even a bit smaller than 1 second) and subsequent jumps get shorter and shorter.
In total, there will be around 5-7 jumps or so... from then on playback works just fine (until I repeat the process, pause, wait a while, resume). Also, with the same hardware, this used to work "previously" (whenever that was exactly, I do not remember), so it must be some sort of regression.
When using software decoding, no such problems occur. Now first I though it may be an issue in `mpv`, so I wanted to try with another player and used `vlc` for that. Again with hw decoding enabled (`--ffmpeg-hw`). I do basically the same as above, pause a video, do some other stuff, resume playback. Here things become interesting:
`vlc` does not suffer from jumps in the video, it seems, instead there are periods where the audio is either silent or distorted. Again, it happens a few times (not really sure whether the periods get shorter, as the jumps in the video with `mpv` seem to do) and then it's resolved and playback continues just fine. Even more interesting, if I have a video in both, `mpv` and `vlc`, at pause (for a while) and resume in one of the two... and wait until the issue resolves there... if then ("right afterwards") I resume in the other, the issue doesn't seem to occur in that. Some versions (ask if you need any other data): - running Debian unstable - kernel 6.4.4 - Xorg / Cinnamon - mpv 0.36.0 - vlc 3.0.13-8-g41878ff4f2 - MESA 23.1.4 - libva2 2.19.0 - i965-va-driver 2.4.1 - intel-media-va-driver 23.2.3 - GPU is integrated in the 12th Gen Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-1270P ``` $ vainfo libva info: VA-API version 1.19.0 libva info: Trying to open /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/dri/iHD_drv_video.so libva info: Found init function __vaDriverInit_1_18 libva info: va_openDriver() returns 0 vainfo: VA-API version: 1.19 (libva 2.12.0) vainfo: Driver version: Intel iHD driver for Intel(R) Gen Graphics - 23.2.3 () vainfo: Supported profile and entrypoints VAProfileNone : VAEntrypointVideoProc VAProfileNone : VAEntrypointStats VAProfileMPEG2Simple : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileMPEG2Main : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileH264Main : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileH264Main : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileH264High : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileH264High : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileJPEGBaseline : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileJPEGBaseline : VAEntrypointEncPicture VAProfileH264ConstrainedBaseline: VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileH264ConstrainedBaseline: VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileVP8Version0_3 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCMain : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCMain : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileHEVCMain10 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCMain10 : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileVP9Profile0 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileVP9Profile0 : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileVP9Profile1 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileVP9Profile1 : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileVP9Profile2 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileVP9Profile2 : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileVP9Profile3 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileVP9Profile3 : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileHEVCMain12 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCMain422_10 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCMain422_12 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCMain444 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCMain444 : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileHEVCMain444_10 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCMain444_10 : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileHEVCMain444_12 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCSccMain : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCSccMain : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileHEVCSccMain10 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCSccMain10 : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileHEVCSccMain444 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCSccMain444 : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileAV1Profile0 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCSccMain444_10 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCSccMain444_10 : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP ``` Any ideas? Thanks,
Chris.

issue.title: jumps in either the video or the audio when using hardware accelleration for video playback
issue.body:
Hey. Shamelessly copying my own bug report at https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/drm/intel/-/issues/9065 from where I was redirected to `libva`.
Not sure whether this is actually an issue in ~i915~ `libva`, since there are probably quite a few other libs/etc. that may be involved.
If you have a better clue, please redirect me accordingly. Let me first describe the issue. Since quite a while now (> 1 year) the following happens when playing back a video with `mpv` (which I've configured to use hw decoding (`hwdec=auto` in `.config/mpv/mpv.conf`):
When I pause the video an wait a while, e.g. leave fullscreen, go do another workspace, do some work, etc. ... after coming back and resuming playback of the video, either right at the beginning of that (or shortly afterwards, like 10s), there are a series of "jumps" in the video. That is I see that the motion is not fluent anymore and the video resumes at a later point.
The audio is **not** affected but play just smoothly.
The jumps are first longer (may 1 second or perhaps 2 at most... maybe also even a bit smaller than 1 second) and subsequent jumps get shorter and shorter.
In total, there will be around 5-7 jumps or so... from then on playback works just fine (until I repeat the process, pause, wait a while, resume). Also, with the same hardware, this used to work "previously" (whenever that was exactly, I do not remember), so it must be some sort of regression.
When using software decoding, no such problems occur. Now first I though it may be an issue in `mpv`, so I wanted to try with another player and used `vlc` for that. Again with hw decoding enabled (`--ffmpeg-hw`). I do basically the same as above, pause a video, do some other stuff, resume playback. Here things become interesting:
`vlc` does not suffer from jumps in the video, it seems, instead there are periods where the audio is either silent or distorted. Again, it happens a few times (not really sure whether the periods get shorter, as the jumps in the video with `mpv` seem to do) and then it's resolved and playback continues just fine. Even more interesting, if I have a video in both, `mpv` and `vlc`, at pause (for a while) and resume in one of the two... and wait until the issue resolves there... if then ("right afterwards") I resume in the other, the issue doesn't seem to occur in that. Some versions (ask if you need any other data): - running Debian unstable - kernel 6.4.4 - Xorg / Cinnamon - mpv 0.36.0 - vlc 3.0.13-8-g41878ff4f2 - MESA 23.1.4 - libva2 2.19.0 - i965-va-driver 2.4.1 - intel-media-va-driver 23.2.3 - GPU is integrated in the 12th Gen Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-1270P ``` $ vainfo libva info: VA-API version 1.19.0 libva info: Trying to open /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/dri/iHD_drv_video.so libva info: Found init function __vaDriverInit_1_18 libva info: va_openDriver() returns 0 vainfo: VA-API version: 1.19 (libva 2.12.0) vainfo: Driver version: Intel iHD driver for Intel(R) Gen Graphics - 23.2.3 () vainfo: Supported profile and entrypoints VAProfileNone : VAEntrypointVideoProc VAProfileNone : VAEntrypointStats VAProfileMPEG2Simple : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileMPEG2Main : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileH264Main : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileH264Main : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileH264High : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileH264High : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileJPEGBaseline : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileJPEGBaseline : VAEntrypointEncPicture VAProfileH264ConstrainedBaseline: VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileH264ConstrainedBaseline: VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileVP8Version0_3 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCMain : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCMain : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileHEVCMain10 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCMain10 : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileVP9Profile0 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileVP9Profile0 : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileVP9Profile1 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileVP9Profile1 : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileVP9Profile2 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileVP9Profile2 : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileVP9Profile3 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileVP9Profile3 : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileHEVCMain12 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCMain422_10 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCMain422_12 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCMain444 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCMain444 : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileHEVCMain444_10 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCMain444_10 : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileHEVCMain444_12 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCSccMain : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCSccMain : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileHEVCSccMain10 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCSccMain10 : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileHEVCSccMain444 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCSccMain444 : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP VAProfileAV1Profile0 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCSccMain444_10 : VAEntrypointVLD VAProfileHEVCSccMain444_10 : VAEntrypointEncSliceLP ``` Any ideas? Thanks,
Chris.

comment.body:
Hmm, it seems that some update has fixed this recently (after the issue existed for probably a year or rather even longer.

And since there wasn't any `mpv` update recently, I'd say hat the bug was in fact in some graphics library (no idea, though, which).

Anyway, closing this therefore.

Thanks,
Chris.

backend driver need some usage hint to optimize the operation

Signed-off-by: Carl Zhang <carl.zhang@intel.com>
